The boys play with their dog, SHEP Their mother smiles, content. Life has covered her with blessing. There is not she sees but it means her good. Her heart, it seems, is especially drawn to her middle so the sweetest, most genial of the boys. The sun is setting in the west. A doorbell rings.

Can I do anything? She shakes her head. She lets him kiss her, but generally seems unaware of him. She notices nothing; says nothing. He must be strong. There will be time enough for tears. H grieves for her more than for himself -- that she should stricken in this way, a woman so faithful, kind and uprig who through the whole of her life has denied herself -~ w has loved the good -- given to the poor, comforted the desolate. A flashforward: Men rise up and bow when she pa by.
Friends have come to visit.
You did everything in the world to make him happy. No one could have had a better life.
He was such a fine boy.
-- Such a fine musician! The sweetest child I ever saw.

It's all so bitter now, hut-- you'll have lovely memories of him. Those can't be taken away. The memories are a torment to her, not a consolation.

He's at peace. Let them live in their naive illusion. If only she still could! To hear his name spoken is more than she can bear. Does no one understand? Now, when others look at her, they glance quickly away. S is aware of being an uncomfortable presence to everyone s meets, particularly when she speaks.
.-.He's in God's hands now.  Where is God? Where was he then? Nature gives no answer, whispers not a word. The child was in God's hands the who time, was he not?

+.-He didn't suffer. He's better off where he is... It's so hard —- you can do everything right, and still -- Their voices seem far away, as though they were speaking her through a tunnel. The best woman in the whole town!

She still has two left. She overhears their voices after they are gone. How much easily they speak as soon as they are out of her presence Not just her child -- it seems that all creation has died Nature has betrayed the heart that loved it. A child appears with a casserole.

Her husband, too, attempts to console her. But having an equal cause for sorrow, he is no more convincing than her friends have been. Grief so deep has made her unfamiliar to him; almost holy Still he must say something.

We have -- to be strong -- for them -- for the other boys. We can't let them see -- (she looks away) I haven't been the husband you deserve -~ I haven't loved you enough -- still -- let me into your “ heart. Let us share the grief.

I never got a chance to tell him -- how sorry I was! I made him unhappy -- anxious -- I did it out of love! Forgive me! She hesitates, waits until she can swallow back a sob to speak -- then can find nothing to say. What did they do t bring such a calamity on themselves? I'm going to be strong for him, That's what he'd want, and ‘that's what he's going to get. An empty swing. A slide. A bridge. Grass fading in the Au heat. . He takes her into his arms. How small their differences s now! He loves her wholly. They are one at last, in grief.
Do we say we have three boys, or two? (in a whisper) I hate my life -- I want to die -- to” with him ~- my child! She will not be consoled. We looks at her, helpless.

(suddenly) Whatever I say, don't believe it. Alone, she prays. She hears no answering voice. Mr. O'Brien closes the lid of his piano. Her soul is gone. Her good. She goes about her life; she walks, eats, sleeps, wakes up. But she does not live. Eac place, each hour is the same. The best of her lay in his soul. She lived through him, s through his eyes. Gradually we become aware of Jack, their eldest son, grow now. The others have tried and failed to console his moth How shall he?

It broke your heart. Never afterwards were you the same -- your faith in goodness shaken -- though carefully you kept it secret, lest our faith be shaken, too. (she walks alone) In vain! We knew! Gone. He has left the world a shar A friend whispers in M O'Brien's ear: .

Teach me the way to you. The oak tree in the front yard. Its roots fgach down into darkness of the earth, towards its cemfer Qnd source. The branches spread towards the light, towards _discovery and utterance; a fountain of life.
Brother, dear brother -- We had one heart within us. One soul -- where you left off and I began, I could not tell. The immovable trunk, a universe of leaves spreading above whispering; an oracle.
Wher are you? How shall I find you again? I will go in search of you -- through all the worlds. The camera rises Vhrough the branches, seeks a way toward the sky above.

Brother, speak through me! Guide me! Answer me from where you are! See what I was, what I am now! Lend your spirit to this song! He discovers himself on the verge of falling asleep at th wheel of a car. He fights to stay awake. The car is drift off the road, and still he cannot rouse himself to consciousness, to the required act of will. A hand touches his shoulder, waking him —-

Jack wakes to find himself in that landscape of paralysis despair which today goes by the name of a city. The famil world has assumed a threatening aspect. A number of scenes with the adult Jack follow encounters friends and strangers. To avoid interrupting the flow of narrative, we will not specify them here.’ From time to t we hear Jack's thoughts. He leads us through the story. The cutting is quick and staccato, to suggest the fractur quality of modern life. His eyes are bright with longing. He never lingers anywhe for long but is forever off, forever moving ‘on. Where di go wrong, or wander from the path? The stars are washed out. The sky is a haze. The moon shi down like any other senseless light, high above the tower steel and glass. Where in these streets can he find any evidence of the world's order, any sign to help him on hi way? The others do not meet his eyes. Each makes his way alone shut up within himself. None can be sure of the other. No is fixed or lasting. Like a bird trapped inside a room, beating against the windows and ceiling, the soul struggles for a time, then sinks down in defe. The buildings hem him round like the trees of a wild fore A false nature; & unwerse of death. A sightless world, roofed over, shut off from things above. Here one must st to walk. A world that would exclude the transcendent, tha says: I am, and there is nothing else. A world without lo It seems he could escape if only he could bring himself t will it. Somehow he cannot. He has gone to sleep, he cann wake up. He wakes from one dream to another. The sights of a modern city: it could be Chicago, New Yor Houston, Paris, Mumbai, Los Angeles, or a composite of th all. We never see it whole -- no skyline or defining monu -- fragments only -- a frenzy of things and people on the move -- a continuous flow of trains and cars -- a new Bab Change seems the only constant in this city; disappearanc loss. Being is a shadow. There is nothing but this endles flux. Nothing eternal, nothing sure.  10. In the faces of strangers that anguished look of our time which betrays itself beneath the smiles and courtesy -- which, increasingly, even children wear. Each a shadow to the other, each with his own eyes fixed the ground in front of him, absorbed in his private world Spectators in a movie theater.

Sweet brother -- you who filled our hearts with light -- who drew us close, who made us one -- a family, a home -- gone. Into the night which has no dawn. He stops, listens. The grey light of 4 television flicker the ceiling of a lonely apartment.. Somewhere a couple ra and howl at each other. Time lapse shots of tall buildings, with clouds passing a them. Hallways. Offices at night. Walls.

What was it. that you pointed to -- knew better than I? You overlooked insult and injury. Were gentle, kind -- Nothing adds up, or leads to anything else. He lives in succession. The shadows of passérsby on the street. A dry streambed. garden in winter, The stiff, dead stalks of sunflowers; t heads bowed in defeat.

Speakllet me hear -- see! Let it not have been in vain! Sing with me -- through me -- you, the true artist -- lend me your strength! ‘Everything conspires to lead one to go on as before. To in the tomb. To sleep. The concrete banks of the L.A. river. Nature is dying. Without nature, will the spirit die? The eye flits here a there, like a frightened bird. The others guess nothing of his condition, and he speaks a word. What would he say? Fog from the beach. Faces, indistinct.  11.

I knew such things happened, but -- it seemed they wouldn't touch me. I could have been with him ~- Her voice fades out, and she is gone. In a moment of fant he finds himself swept along in a river. The waters rise, threatening to engulf him. Now he finds himself inside a burning house. Smoke slides under the door. Flames peel the paint from the ceiling. H stuffs his fist in his mouth to keep from screaming. The others neither speak nor act, as though they lay under so spell or enchantment. A stranger with a Walkman. A driver in Q traffic jam.

Losing you, I lost: my way Physical life in a world abandoned by the spirit. Organiz unreality. The soul a hindrance in one's dealings here. A burden. A mere quantity of thoughts and desires. One is without form and void. Thousand-minded. At odds wi himself. A miscellany, not a man. Cold public works. The city; the lost creation; the cosmo become a Cave. Travelers on a New York subway. All await a new Creation. None knows how to bring it fort He finds himselF on an Orliner. It skims over the tops of the trees, rising and falling, struggling to stay aloft. flies under power lines, narrowly avoids houses and apart buildings. The other passengers have gone to sleep, or pa attention. The roar of the senses; loud, ever louder. Sensation beco substance. The false world so surrounds us that it taken place of nature. This is a new death; death of the spirit, extinction of t soul. The supreme misery: to be cheated of the sight of essence find oneself abandoned to the busy dance of things which away. What is despair but to lose the eternal?  12. Forms dissolve like thoughts, like shapes in a waterfall. Newspaper headlines. Fragments of TV shows. Swarming fact Walls, security lights, traffic. A dark, empty cathedral. Where are you to find the spring and source of life? Will die before you do?

Lead me from the unreal to.the real. Lead me from darkness to light. Lead me from death to eternal life. To what end is nature? Is there nothing but this chaos, t congeries of scraps and fragments? N ing, which binds the together? A new hell; entirely of our times; a glass box. The sky i covered over. Man has shut himself in. He must find a way out. He must journey through time, fro the outward and external to the heart of creation. A solitary tree in the middle of a parking lot. A clock. closed door. A porch light. A lame man limping down the street. The images follow on each other in quick successi The sound snaps in and out. He finds himself on a high building. He leaps off the edg into thin air, without giving a thought to how he might survive the fall. He wakes up with a gasp. A figure stands near him. He cannot see its face, but he feels a strange peace Flow into him; a sense of radiant l Who are you? Jack seemS 4» ask. Why can I not come to you The figure points towards a gate. Beyond it lies a field. Trembling, Jack looks back towards the city. Come out! the figure seems to say. There is that near you which will guide you, if only you trust its lead. The figure reaches out, touches the crown of Jack's head, then is gone. Jack looks around. Where to begin? Night lifts off like a fog. The street lamps flicker out. morning star burns in a gap between the tall buildings -- solitary, unheeded -- a promise of that world which here but a legend. You -- who are you? The star seems to address him.  13. Beneath the artificial world, the true face of creation, covered over, obscured, beckoning us still. He closes his eyes. He would rather sleep than undertake necessary struggle. He awaits a command that has already given. Let us sing a new song, tell a new story; one which, mind of the ancient tales, takes its inspiration from science, Let us search for the permanent amid the fleeting and mutable, for that which endures through the spectacle of ceaseless change. Let us discover the eternal, the good. Jack walks along the Santa Monica shore. Surfers bob up a down. in the line-up. Children play in We tide. Their laughter, their wild cries, take Inm back +o the past, to childhood and beyond it, to the world's owq -- to the fir light of creation. At the edge of the city, he sees a tree. He reaches out t touch it. The instant he does, the universe springs up fr its source.

We show the growth of the cosmos, the great epic of evolution, from the Big Bang through the long ages of geological time, down to the present day. We begin in the chaos or nothingness out of which space a time arose -- in a r@alm beyond our power to imagine, wit form or coherence, void of here and now. Suddenly, like j replacing sadness and brooding, light breaks forth, and t universe is born Molecular clouds gather to make galaxies, which sail out through the void like ships on a sea without shores. New stars, new worlds are born and pass away, like wasted see They are the furnaces in which the elements of our future life are smelted. Many experiments must be tried and reje before our system is hit upon; much labor expended, with continual improvements through the long ages. At last the ancestral earth appears; a bulb of gases, mor like a star than a planet, seared by the sun's fire, glow like a coal from deep within. The gases cool to liquid. A solid core falls out; a thin crust forms. From time to time the vapors clear away to reveal a mighty inferno of magma and pitch.  14. The sky fills with steam. Rains fall for millennia, cooli the surface by degrees. For ages there. is no clear day o sun, no night of stars; only thunder and lightning. But b and by the mists drift off, the clouds part and the first land appears, a low island of meteoritic rubble and stark volcanic stone. With no plants to hold the land in place, wind and water carve the stone into fantastic shapes. Shadows move mathematically over the hills. The vast wastes wait for nothing. Each day is like the last. In the boiling waters of a hot spring, entities develop t can maintain their integrity in thefage of disturbance fr without. They do not endure by maintaining their rigidity They are soft and yielding. They resist change by themsel changing endlessly, like.a whirlpool, inventing variation themselves which protect them from injury and accident an gradually create a world more favorable +0 their growth. We cannot tell precisely when or how life begins. It come not as a unique event, at a precise stroke of the clock. first living things are simple thermophiles; odd, margina forms, neither plant nor animal, barely over the indefina line which separates the animate from the inanimate. They drift in solitude through the vast, lifeless sea, beneath the incandescent skies of a planet still racked b volcanic eruptions and menaced by the impact of comets an asteroids. In areas protected from the wind, colonies of bacteria ap as scums and muds, ‘tinting the shores along the water- courses, like bathtub rings. They have no predators; deat something yet unknown. Microbial mats appear _at the edges of the tides. They in give rise to stromatolites; hard, chalky knobs of rock, shaped like cabbages or cauliflowers, the architecture of generations of cyanobacteria living on top of each other, like coral in a reef. Bacteria that once preyed on each other learn gradually t live in community. As such communities become hereditary, first cells with a nucleus arise. Together the bacteria arrive at a result which none by itself could have achiev From the beginning, cooperation plays as great a part as competition in the ascent of life. It succeeds where nake power and selfishness do not, making the deadliest enemie indispensable to each other's survival. The struggle for existence is not life's sole or fundamental law.  is. Slowly the bacteria creep inland, spreading over the volc debris like a layer of felt. Plants, magic jewel boxes of chlorophyll, soon abound. Instead of drawing nourishment their surroundings, they produce it for themselves, transforming sunlight and carbon into living tissue. Photosynthesis has made life self-sufficient, just at the moment it was living on borrowed time, in danger of eatin every particle of nourishment in the sea. Now life can manufacture its own food -- no longer depend on getting i already made, from a source outside itself. Some of the plants, lacking chlorophyll, find it easier t prey on others than to manufacture ‘heir own nourishment lean water and sunlight. Thus the First animals arise; Li robbing life; assassins. Alien as they appear, they show the beginnings of need, o purpose and will; the unmistakable marks Of identity, the first true signs of self. Something new has taken root in nature; something which is not driven by external forces set in motion from within,. prompted by itself and nothin else. Colonies of animals arise in which the functions of life cleverly divided. Multicellular creatures spread through seas using every foothold they can find to establish an existence, no matter how narrow or constraining it might first appear. We see the creation, not as an event in the distant past, result of a finished and forgotten act, but rather as something which happens in every moment of time: no less miracle now, ths present hour, than it was in the beginni The film is like asteve, sifting the seed from the husk o appearances, the changeless from the changing. Volvox, sponges, sea fans, anemones, corals and jellyfish the creatures fill the newly hospitable waters in inexhaustible numbers. There are no fish as yet; no crabs shrimp or lobster. And yet it’ is an age of unparalleled opportunity; for the first time, now and never again, a w free of competition. The wildest fancies are permitted; anything can find a place. Bizarre beings spring up from sea's imagination, then vanish forever: Hallucingenia, Opabinia, Anomalocaris. Segmented worms appear, and after them the first vertebra simple fish. Spines and jaws allow the vertebrates to lea the sea floor, to give up grubbing in the mud for nourish in order to prey on larger creatures.  16. Predators shape their prey, driving them to develop stron armor, greater dexterity and speed. Wondrous fact, that h life not been compelled to face the threat of a violent death, it might never have risen above the ooze. Death comes as a late arrival to the creation, to give li greater capability and scope -- paradoxically, to make it stronger and more lasting. The light flashes at the water's surface above, beckoning higher. Algae spread up from the sea. Mosses and liverwor appear. Here, on land, the plants need not contend for li They seem to rejoice in their new independence, to reach with the vigor of beings unexpectedly set free. By and by the hills are carpeted with a mat of diminutive green vegetation. Frost and lichens break down the rocks into a soil fit fo the more developed plants still waiting by the shore. Horseshoe crabs come up onto the shore to lay their eggs. water, rich as beer, froths and foams around them. Where before there was no sound of life, now we hear the faint, familiar choir of insects. Millipedes forage on the mud flats. Scorpions and ghost crabs come out of the surf to on them. Silverfish follow, and soon winged relatives are evidence. With the power of flight, the insects can range and wide in search of food, scatter their seed and escape their enemies, though as yet no enemy has appeared. Is nature mere weather, doing and undoing without end? Wh does it work toward? What purpose does it have in view? Nothing stands still Or keeps its place. All is growth an ceaseless unfolding. One force works in all, advancing swiftly from form to form, never lingering in any single forever rushing 09; Witnin all things, but not enclosed; outside all, but not eycluded. From time to time, lest we forget that we are sharing our hero's perspective, we cuit back to Jack in the city, goi through the motions of his everyday life. The first fishes with amphibian traits gain the shore. Sw and marshland have replaced the wide, windy plains of the preceding ages. The forms of vegetation are simple, few. There are no reeds or grasses. No flower breaks the gloom The earth is a vast, wet Eden. Except near the poles, the are no seasons. Each year is like the last. Reptiles emerge from the amphibians, and dinosaurs in tur from the reptiles. Among the dinosaurs we discover the fi signs of maternal love, as the creatures learn to care fo each other.  17. Is not love, too, a work of the creation? What should we been without it? How had things been then? Silent as a shadow, consciousness has slipped into the wo The plant kingdom, too, advances as the first seed plants emerge: cycads, araucarias, conifers and gingkos. Exaltin music alternates with long stretches of peaceful sound; w and waves and summer crickets. Nature seems everywhere to be leading toward’ something. this delay in arriving at its ends? Why does it feel its along -- wander, dawdle, delay? Why twist and turn and backtrack, as though it were finding its way through a ma Why establish hindrances and obstad@S only to put itself the trouble of devising stratagems for overcoming them? Mammals peer out from their hiding places if the trees, waiting for the cold of night to descend and reduce the reptiles to inactivity. None is larger than a squirrel, f larger than a mouse. They are a thin, precarious line -- inconspicuous in the general landscape, holding on agains great odds, in constant danger of being extinguished altogether. This is the fate that befalls the dinosaurs instead, as a large asteroid slams into the earth, covering it for year a pall of dust. The plants die off; the larger reptiles starve. For long years the earth lies fallow. Gradually t mammals come forth to take up those niches which the dinosaurs have left vacant. Nature seems to waste and blunder cruelly. And yet, excep for this disaster, the dinosaurs might have dominated the earth down tothe present day. How strange that calamity a disease should lead life forward ~~ prove indispensable t its unfolding -- that such grandeur should rise up froma foundation of pain and death and ruin! The ichneumon wasp, the crocodile, the shark -- to think they, too, were the fruit of long, painstaking labor and calculation -- brought forth with an equal care! To think that they now go patiently about their tasks, burning wit life as real as ours! Grasses and modern birds now make their appearance; soon thereafter, the first primates. At last we come to man, t triumph of the earth, paragon of creatures and miracle of miracles. He walks with head aloft, his shoulders broad a strong, his gaze fixed on the heavens, the crown and glor creation. .  18. We suggest, in quick succession, the steps by which he mo from a life of nomadic savagery to a settled, stable cult He tames the reindeer and the wild sheep. He thatches his roof to keep out the shafts of rain. He draws furrows thr the earth and guides the water to his fields. What a short time our race has occupied this globe, what late arrival we are after all -- a beginning -- creatures more of the future than of the past! An unspeakably great future it might be, and yet, though nature should be sufficient to our wants, we have set ourselves against it and against each other. Everything sings in the great chorus;each knows its place and is happy. Man alone does not. i Even now we live in the first day. The splendor of nature's © distant beginni shines within us. Yet somehow we have lost our way. Tares stand among the grain: bright red poppies, thistles thorns. The ravaged earth. The ruins of ancient cities. G walls thrown down by war. Dry, abandoned wells. The stone head of some ancient god, buried to his neck in sand. A temple engulfed by the sea. Why does the world lie broken and in heaps? Where did it go wrong? Our hero is left, if not quite where he was before, nevertheless in-doubt and misgiving. He trusted nature to answer his questions. It answers some but raises others i turn. We have lost the eternal ~~ within us and without. How di first come to pass? How does it happen even now, today, i the life of each and all? A ladder, leading up into a tree. A spring, running from rock. A rose. How shall we recover the eternal which. increasingly we s for, without knowing how we should?

The souls keep close together. Presently, OMe comes forwa from among the rest: a boy. Helpers -- we C@nnot see thei faces -- whisper in his ear. One motions him to come towa a door. He hesitates. A woman in a bridal gown, her face covered by a veil, sho him her wedding ring; a field of sunflowers; gives him a book which he must eat.

In quick cuts, the child looks back at the house from whi he came. Already it seems far away. He sees the porch light of his future home. Moths hover a the yellow lamp. A figure whispers in his e@or - A hand motions him forwar he stands by a Wide riv@r His POV, as though from a boat coming out of the darkness of a sea-cave, into the light.

We return to the opening of the movie: to the tall oak tr in front of the O'Brien's house. A thousand ages to lay down a bed of mud, a thousand more shape a leaf or build a tree -- and all this labor to pre a living soul! The soul: the crown and apex of creation: the self, the center and inside of nature. Great not in space and time, in capacity, in depth and power of apprehension. Where do it come from? When is it first born? How does it advance? Towards what? How does it happen that I am I, and you are you?  20. The slow, dark birth of the soul -- greater, more mysteri than the birth of worlds.

The world is not yet something completely known and real. continues to seem as though some nook or passageway might give them access to another land. Bye; baby bunting, Daddy's gone a- hunting, to get a little rabbit skin She kisses RL goodnight- She shuts out the light. The fan turns back and forth.In their young hearts, she is the na for God.

Leave it on. The tiny nightlight watches over their sleep, burning eve through the long hours until morning. In the moonlight the bushes assume a tropical size; the leaves are painted silver. Nothing.
Can you push the chest of drawers against the wall? There is a narrow crack between them. What might slide in through it? Jack feels lean and alone in the vast palace the night.
Now sleep -- like good boys. The shadows dance on the ceiling. tt is ‘hough they were alive. Strange faces peer out at them from the darkness. Nothing stands still. Things come and go, ebb and flow.

Why does the moon follow me? No sooner has she left the room, than the boys are up and about. They bounce on their beds. They inspect the glowin tubes in the back of the radio. They take voyages under t sheets and blankets. They hold a flashlight underneath th faces.

When their mother com@s in later, she at first cannot loc them. One child is under his bed, another sleeping on the floor. She lifts +hem up, and puts them back in their pla kisses them and closes the door. Light shines through the keyhole. His infancy has passed away, as though in a single day. His innocence is ended.

Jack wakes up. All is as it was before. Where was he? The sweetgum tree that was planted at his brother's birth mar the passage of five years. His eyes until now have been shielded from the sight of e suffering and death; his family united, with no hint of contradiction between his mother and father. The world coheres. Things assume their conventional names take their customary places. We settle into the main epoc the story.  30. Jack is now 11 years old, in 6th grade, his brothers 9 an RL is a gentle boy, loved by all, quiet and generous, wit good sense of humor. Steve is combative, wild, but brave loyal, too. A title card reads: "TEXAS, 1956". Where before we kept entirely to the family's house, we n shall venture farther and farther into the neighborhood a eventually out into the town in central Texas where they live, far from the world at large. The neighbors' yards are shaded by oak trees and surround by low hedges that the children have cut gaps through. Th O'Brien house stands with five or six others on the last street in a subdivision. Its front is turned towards the other houses. Behind it lie the open woods: rolling hills juniper, broken here and there by Cow pastures.

Now that the heat of the afternoon is past, the neighbors their hoses out. The sprinklers start up with a cough. Standing with their sleeves rolled up, the men regard the gravely, each adjusting his faucet until the water falls precisely to the lawn's perimeter. She is preparing dinner. She notices that the children ha grown steadily more quiet and watchful.

Did you swepthe patio, honey? Did you gebyour room? The boys go quickly about their chores. They sweep up the patio and wet it down with a hose to make it look fresh. pull up a few handfuls of. crab grass and leave them in a conspicuous place. Then, in the distance, they see a gree Studebaker approaching.
The tires hiss on the concrete. The boys are still and expectant. A moment later their father steps through the front door.

Hi, sweetheart! Boys!  31. He kisses their mother and turns to face them. They do no know quite how to act with him. He catches them up into h arms -- physically shows them every sign of affection -- they are wary of him and hold themselves apart. They understand that he is devoted to them. He would never aba them, no, but always protect them. Still they do not trus him. He pours himself a shot of rye, passes the glass back and forth under his nose, then tosses it down. He shows Jack a patch of their lawn tnat ‘5 overrun with grass and burrs.

Did you pick the weeds along the side of the house? Or only where I could see? (Jack shakes his head) They're back again. You need to pull them up by the roots. You can't just yank off the tops. He shows Jack what he means. To the child it seems the we must run off to tk nd of the earth; a labor beyond his strength.

Lord, bless this house, and all those who live within it. Bless this food to our use, and us to thy loving and faithful service, and make us ever mindful of the needs of others. Amen. Am I dreaming?

Sir.

"Yes, Sir." It didn't look like it. We'll see. The boys regard him warily. His sharp, sarcastic words, a orders so irrational he hardly expects that they will be obeyed. We've got to go. Howard gives them a blank, haunted look. Then, without sa a word, he turns and heads home. One afternoon with his mother, Jack sees a lame man hobbl along the sidewalk. He watches in pity and horror as the man limps away. That shape could be his. Some days afterwards his grandmother is visiting. Her bri spirits do not distract him from noticing her arthritic hands, the veins in her arms, her bunioned feet projectin off the end of the ttoman. Everyone. Look at Shep! He remembers Austin, the skinny boy who could not stop pacing. Nothing. I can walk. Howard does not seem surprised. He makes no protest. Jack shakes his hand, in an awkward effort to reassure hi his friendship. Rusty peers out of his room at the older boys. He has been quiet the whole time.

There's nothing like that, is there? She frowns. He cannot tell her what is disturbing him. Th no longer speak with one voice. He has descended into the world of duality.
That night his mother says a prayer by their beds; a rare occurrence. While she hears their prayers, she does not o join in them. They glance at each other.
